verses.text: Why are times not set by the Almighty, and why do those who know Him never see His days?
verses.comment: Job expresses anguish at God's apparent silence and lack of judgment. This verse reveals the ancient longing for an appointed day of justice, which is later fulfilled in Christ's final judgment (cf. Matthew 25:31-46).

verses.text: Some remove boundary stones; they seize flocks and pasture them for themselves.
verses.comment: The removal of boundary stones was strictly forbidden (Deut. 19:14) and symbolizes a profound injustice, highlighting humanity's need for a Redeemer who restores original justice.

verses.text: They drive away the donkey of the fatherless and take the widow's ox as a pledge.
verses.comment: This verse emphasizes oppression of the vulnerable, a concern echoed frequently in scripture (see James 1:27), and sets the stage for Christ's care for the marginalized.

verses.text: They push the needy out of the way; the poor of the land must hide themselves together.
verses.comment: Here, Job notes the cruelty of the wicked towards the poor, showcasing the early biblical vision of social justice that is further revealed in the teachings of Christ (cf. Luke 6:20-21).

verses.text: Like wild donkeys in the desert, the poor go out working for food, searching for sustenance in the wasteland for their children.
verses.comment: The poor are likened to wild donkeys—untamed and alone, a vivid image for the human condition without divine shepherding.

verses.text: They reap their neighbor's field for food and gather the leftovers from the vineyard of the wicked.
verses.comment: Job describes the poor as forced to glean, a practice regulated by law (Lev. 19:10), hinting at the tension between law and its abuse—later resolved by Christ's fulfillment of the law (Matt. 5:17).

verses.text: They spend the night naked, without covering, and have no protection from the cold.
verses.comment: Job paints the suffering of the destitute in terms reminiscent of Psalm 22, which is later applied to Christ's own passion and vulnerability.

verses.text: They are soaked by mountain rains and cling to the rock for shelter.
verses.comment: ‘Clinging to the rock’ subtly anticipates Christ as the true rock and refuge (cf. 1 Corinthians 10:4), suggesting hope for ultimate shelter in God's steadfastness.

verses.text: The fatherless are snatched from the breast; the poor are taken as security for a debt.
verses.comment: This verse highlights how the vulnerable suffer merciless treatment, violating laws meant to protect them—a persistent biblical theme culminating in Christ's advocacy for all.

verses.text: They go about naked, without clothing, hungry as they carry sheaves.
verses.comment: Job’s description anticipates later condemnations of economic injustice and greed, which Christ frequently opposes in the Gospels.

verses.text: Among the rows, they press out oil; they tread the winepresses, yet suffer thirst.
verses.comment: Those who labor in abundance yet are denied the fruits of their labor—a motif that finds deeper meaning in Christ’s sacrifice (see Isaiah 63:3).

verses.text: From the city, the dying groan and the wounded cry for help, yet God does not charge wrongdoing against them.
verses.comment: Job struggles with God's justice, underscoring the mystery of suffering—a theme realized fully in the Cross (cf. Romans 8:18-23).

verses.text: There are those who rebel against the light, who do not know its ways nor stay in its paths.
verses.comment: The theme of 'light' recurs in the New Testament, where Christ is the light of the world, revealing and overcoming darkness (John 8:12).

verses.text: Before dawn, the murderer rises to kill the poor and needy; at night, he is like a thief.
verses.comment: The verse contrasts light and darkness, suggesting that evil works best in secret—a condition transformed by Christ, who brings all hidden things to light.

verses.text: The adulterer waits for twilight, thinking, 'No eye will see me,' and disguises his face.
verses.comment: Sin seeks concealment, yet God eventually exposes all things (cf. Luke 12:2-3), reinforcing the need for repentance and authentic conversion.

verses.text: They break into houses in the darkness; by day they shut themselves in, they do not know the light.
verses.comment: The depraved choose darkness over light—themes later used by Christ to illustrate spiritual blindness and the necessity of grace for enlightenment.

verses.text: For them, the morning is deep darkness; they are friends with the terrors of the night.
verses.comment: Job describes spiritual and moral darkness, foreshadowing the condemnation of those who reject Christ the light (see John 1:4-5).

verses.text: They are swift on the surface of the waters; their portion in the land is cursed; they turn not toward the way of the vineyards.
verses.comment: An image of instability and curse for the wicked—justice may be hidden, but God’s ultimate righteousness prevails in Christ.

verses.text: Drought and heat consume the snow waters, so does Sheol consume sinners.
verses.comment: The inevitability of judgment is expressed through vivid natural imagery, foreshadowing the New Testament teaching on divine justice and the final resurrection.

verses.text: The womb will forget him; the worm will feast on him; he will be remembered no more. Wickedness will be broken like a tree.
verses.comment: Describes the transience of the wicked—contrasted with Christ's promise of eternal life for the righteous (cf. John 6:40).

verses.text: He preys on the barren who bears no child, and does no good for the widow.
verses.comment: Job highlights lack of mercy—later, Christ’s concern for the widow and childless becomes a mark of true discipleship (cf. Luke 7:12-15).

verses.text: Yet God drags away the mighty by His power; though they rise, they have no assurance of life.
verses.comment: God's sovereignty over the powerful is emphasized—a precursor to Christ’s teaching that true security is found only in God.

verses.text: God may let them feel secure for a while, but His eyes are on their ways.
verses.comment: The vigilance of God over human conduct is a thread tied throughout scripture, culminating in Christ’s omniscience (cf. John 2:25).

verses.text: They are exalted for a moment, then they are gone; they are brought low and gathered up like all others; they are cut off like the heads of grain.
verses.comment: Job uses harvest imagery to describe the fleeting nature of evil power, echoing Jesus' parables of the final harvest and separation of wicked from righteous.

verses.text: If this is not so, then who can prove me false and make my words nothing?
verses.comment: Job challenges anyone to refute his observations—foreshadowing Christ’s authority and the certainty of divine revelation, which cannot be broken.
